Authors:
Marianne M. Le Roux, James Stephen Boatwright, Ben-Erik Van
Wyk
Title:
Phylogenetics of the genus Crotalaria (Fabaceae) and a
modified infrageneric classification system
Keywords:
Callosities; Crotalaria; Infrageneric classification;
Phylogeny; Section Amphipilosae
Abstract:
Crotalaria is a large genus of 700 species with its centre
of diversity in tropical Africa and Madagascar and secondary radiations
to other parts of the world. The current infrageneric classification
system is based on morphological and taximetric studies (conducted by
Bisby & Polhill) and is here re-evaluated using the molecular
approach. The nuclear ITS, plastid psbA-trnH and two barcoding gene
regions, matK and rbcL were amplified. Sequences were analyzed using
parsimony and model-based (Bayesian) approaches. The resultant molecular
phylogeny allowed for a new interpretation of diagnostically important
morphological characters, including specializations of the calyx, keel,
standard petal and style, which are variously convergent in several
unrelated infrageneric groups. Of particular interest is the almost
perfect congruence between the new phylogeny and the distribution of
standard petal callosity types. A new sectional classification is
proposed and formalized, comprising 10 sections: Hedriocarpae (the least
specialized), Stipulosae, Geniculatae, Amphipilosae, Grandiflorae,
Glaucae, Incanae, Schizostigma, Calycinae and Crotalaria (the most
specialized). A group of species endemic to southern Africa is described
as a new section (Amphipilosae). Sectional limits of the Geniculatae,
Calycinae and Crotalaria are modified. The subsections Stipulosae,
Glaucae and Incanae are raised to sectional level, while some groups
previously recognized as subsections are either abandoned (due to lack
of monophyly Â– subsections Hedriocarpae, Chrysocalycinae, Macrostachyae,
Tetralobocalyx and Crotalaria) or are subsumed under existing sections
(Dispermae and Longirostres).
